affiliation.ce:source-text: University of Bonn, Center for Economic Policy Research, Institute of Labor Economics, Germany
University of Bonn, Center for Economic Policy Research, Germany

head.citation-title: Income and wealth inequality in america, 1949–2016
head.abstracts: © 2020 by The University of Chicago.This paper introduces a new long-run data set based on archival data from historical waves of the Survey of Consumer Finances. Studying the joint distribution of household income and wealth, we expose the central importance of portfolio composition and asset prices for wealth dynamics in postwar America. Asset prices shift the wealth distribution because of systematic differences in household portfolios along the wealth distribution. Middle-class portfolios are dominated by housing, while rich households predominantly own business equity. Differential changes in equity and house prices shaped wealth dynamics in postwar America and decoupled the income and wealth distribution over extended periods.

grant-text.$: We thank Alina Bartscher and Lukas Gehring for outstanding research assistance. We thank participants at the National Bureau of Economic Research Summer Institute, World Inequality Database (WID.world) conference at Paris School of Economics, New Data and New Questions Conference at Arizona State University, Institute for New Economic Thinking (Cambridge), American Economic Association (Philadelphia), Society for Economic Dynamics (Edinburgh), Society for the Advancement of Economic Theory, Swiss Society of Economics and Statistics (St. Gallen), and Fed Listens Conference at Minneapolis as well as seminar participants at Columbia University, Humboldt University of Berlin, Deutsches Institut für Wirtschaftsforschung, Konstanz, Munich, Oslo, St. Louis and Minneapolis Fed, Oesterreichische Nationalbank, New York University, and Vancouver. We are grateful to Christian Bayer, Jesse Bricker, Emma Enderby, Kyle Herkenhoff, Dirk Krüger, Per Krusell, Felix Kubler, Olivier Godechot, Thomas Piketty, Josep Pijoan-Mas, Ed Prescott, José-Víctor Ríos-Rull, Aysegul Sahin, Petr Sedlacek, Thomas Steger, Felipe Valencia, Gustavo Ventura, Gianluca Violante, and Gabriel Zucman for their helpful comments and suggestions. Schularick was supported by the European Research Council. Steins gratefully acknowledges financial support from a scholarship of the Science Foundation of Sparkassen-Finanzgruppe. The usual disclaimer applies. Data are provided as supplementary material online.

coredata.dc:description: © 2020 by The University of Chicago.This paper introduces a new long-run data set based on archival data from historical waves of the Survey of Consumer Finances. Studying the joint distribution of household income and wealth, we expose the central importance of portfolio composition and asset prices for wealth dynamics in postwar America. Asset prices shift the wealth distribution because of systematic differences in household portfolios along the wealth distribution. Middle-class portfolios are dominated by housing, while rich households predominantly own business equity. Differential changes in equity and house prices shaped wealth dynamics in postwar America and decoupled the income and wealth distribution over extended periods.
coredata.dc:title: Income and wealth inequality in america, 1949–2016
